questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought with concerns of having ingested a foreign body. X-ray confirms the presence of a coin in the esophagus. The child is asymptomatic and hemodynamically stable. Which of the following is the appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observe for 24 hours; if the foreign body is not passed in feces, then perform endoscopy.
Perform urgent endoscopy and removal of the foreign body.
Make the child eat bananas, and wait for passage of foreign body in stool.
Provide plenty of fluids orally for safe passage of the foreign body.

questions.solution:
Asymptomatic blunt objects and coins lodged in the esophagus can be observed for up to 24 hours in anticipation of passage into the stomach.

Urgent endoscopic removal is preferred for sharp objects, button batteries in the esophagus, and foreign bodies associated with respiratory symptoms.

Button batteries are very dangerous foreign bodies and must be expediently removed because they can cause

  • Mucosal injury in 1-hour contact time
  • Involve all layers of the esophagus in 4 hours

After suspecting a foreign body in either the trachea or esophagus, plain x-rays of the chest, neck, and abdomen are obtained. Anteroposterior and lateral views are helpful in localizing the objects.

A swallowed coin stuck in the esophagus will appear flat on the anteroposterior view, while the edge will be visible in the lateral view. In the case of coins in the trachea, the findings will be opposite- flat in the lateral view and edge in anteroposterior view. This is because of the difference in dimensions of the trachea and esophagus. 

A button can be differentiated from a coin based on the double-halo and step-off that can be seen in anteroposterior and lateral views.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with concerns about his rapid abdominal enlargement. Further investigations reveal, a Wilm's tumor with a tumor thrombus extending to the heart. This would be staged as:
questions.solution:

Tumor confined to the kidney and completely resected with negative lymph nodes.

Tumor extends beyond the kidney but is completely resected with negative margins and lymph nodes.

Residual tumor present following surgery confined to the abdomen, including gross or microscopic tumor. Extension of tumor thrombus to Inferior vena cava, including the heart.

Hematogenous metastases (lung, liver, bone, brain, etc.)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was brought to OPD  with abrupt onset of fever, generalized lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Blood counts showed a decrease in platelets and RBCs. Bone marrow and peripheral blood smear showed cells as given below. Immunophenotyping revealed the presence of  CD79a+, CD19+, and CD20+. The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing lymphoblasts are suggestive of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL). The cells of origin for these neoplastic cells are precursor B lymphoblasts.

ALL is more common in childhood with a peak incidence around 3-5 years of age. The child had symptoms related to bone marrow suppression including anemia, and fever secondary to infections. These infections are due to neutropenia and generalized lymphadenopathy, indicating the effect of neoplastic infiltration. Hepatosplenomegaly points towards extra-medullary hematopoiesis.

Microscopy reveals lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scanty agranular cytoplasm along with B cell markers like CD79a, CD19, and CD20.

Other options:

Option B: Precursor erythroblasts are cells of myeloid lineage that will have myeloid markers like CD 33, and CD34. Though ALL and AML both have an abrupt onset of presentation and may be difficult to distinguish morphologically. Immunophenotype features will distinguish them. 

Option C: Germinal center B cells will give rise to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL(Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma), or Burkitt lymphoma with characteristic appearances. Moreover, these will have positive CD10 as a marker of the germinal center.

Option D: Thymic origin T-cells will show the presence of T-cell markers.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old boy last vaccinated at 12 weeks of life presents to you with a high-grade fever, cough, and a rash. The parents say that the rash shown below started from the forehead and behind the ears, and then it spread to the neck and body. Which of the following is true regarding this child's condition?
  1. Causative agent is an RNA paramyxovirus
  2. The secondary attack rate in susceptible contacts is ≥90%
  3. Forchheimer spots are characteristic
  4. Jeryl Lynn strain of vaccine is used for prevention
  5. Most complications are due to secondary bacterial infections.
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with the symptoms, incomplete vaccination history, and regional distribution of the red maculopapular rash is suggestive of measles. Options 1,2 and 5 are correct regarding this condition.

Measles is caused by a single-stranded, lipid-enveloped RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash. Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash. They appear as discrete red lesions with bluish-white spots at the level of the premolars. It can also involve the lips and gingiva. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities. The image below shows Koplik's spots.

Confirmation of the diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Management is mainly supportive by the maintenance of hydration and oxygenation. 

Most complications are secondary to bacterial infections. Pneumonia is the most common cause of death and acute otitis media is the most common complication. Croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis are the other complications.

Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition. It is contraindicated in individuals with severe immunosuppression.

Rubella, also known as German measles is a viral disease that presents with low-grade fever, sore throat, rash, and lymphadenopathy. Forchheimer spots are tiny rose-colored lesions or petechial hemorrhages seen on the soft palate. It is usually seen with the onset of the rash. The rash starts on the face and neck and then involves the torso and extremities. It is shown in the image below. 

The Jeryl Lynn strain of virus is used for vaccination against mumps. It is a systemic viral illness caused by a paramyxovirus characterized by parotitis.

It is applicable only for DPT, TT, hepatitis B vaccine, OPV, liquid pentavalent vaccine, rotavirus vaccine(new version with the VVM on the side), and JE vaccines (inactivated). It is not applicable to BCG and measles vaccines. 

Vaccine vials opened in session-site can be used in more than one session up to four weeks if expiry date has not passed, if storage and transport was appropriate, no contamination has occurred in vial septum, asepsis in withdrawing was practiced and if vaccine vial monitor has not reached discard point.

Open vials should not be submerged in water. All open vials should have a record of date and time of opening. At the end of a session, all vaccines should be returned to the cold chain point and segregated as re-usable and non-reusable. All open vials of BCG, measles must be destroyed after 48 hours or before next session, whichever is earlier.

In case of any adverse events following immunization, all open vials should not be discarded until investigation is complete. All vials must be transported in zipper bags in the vaccine carrier and recorded in stock register. Ice packs used should be well sealed.

questions.text: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusion, low hemoglobin level, and target cells in the smear are suggestive of thalassemia. Globin gene sequencing is used for its definitive diagnosis. 

High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used as a screening test for thalassemia (option A). 

Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into α-thalassemia and β-thalassemia.

β-thalassemia is caused by point mutations of the β-thalassemia gene on chromosome 11, which diminish the synthesis of β-globin chains. Splicing mutations are the most common cause of (β+) thalassemia. 

There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in β-thalassemia. Children with severe thalassemia present with distinctive facial features such as maxilla hyperplasia, a flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing. Other manifestations include pathologic bone fractures, significant hepatosplenomegaly, and cachexia. 

Blood smears show marked anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

Hb Electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are used as screening tests for thalassemia. DNA diagnosis to detect β-thalassemia mutations is used for definitive diagnosis. The Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron-deficiency anemia and β-thalassemia trait. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Transfusions are administered every 3-4 weeks to maintain a pretransfusion hemoglobin level of 9.5-10.5 g/dL. Transfusion-induced hemosiderosis is a significant complication in transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Iron deposition occurs in the liver, endocrine organs, and heart, resulting in complications including hypothyroidism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, growth hormone deficiency, hypoparathyroidism, diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and arrhythmias.

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A neonate with vertebral and limb deformities was unable to pass meconium in the last 48 hours. Physical examination reveals abdominal distension with an anal dimple and Wangenstein's invertogram shows a low-lying defect.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is imperforate anus with VACTERL association (presence of vertebral and limb anomalies in addition to the anal atresia).

The neonate will present with an inability to pass meconium, abdominal distension, anal dimple, and sometimes passing meconium per urethra. It is divided into low intermediate and high lyings according to the Wingspread classification. Diagnosis is done using Wangenstein invertogram . Treatment is surgical.

Other options:

Option A: Hirschsprung disease is a congenital condition that occurs due to the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum. It is associated with Downs syndrome. Delayed passage of meconium, abdominal distension, bilious vomiting, and severe chronic constipation are the features. Rectal examination shows a tight sphincter with an empty rectum. X-ray of the abdomen shows intestinal obstruction.

Option B: Meconium ileus is a condition, where thick meconium gets collected in the intestine and obstructs the lumen.  It is classically associated with cystic fibrosis. Features are intestinal obstruction, respiratory dysfunction, and exocrine pancreatic insufficiency with high salty sweat. X-ray shows calcified meconium pellets with air-fluid level (soap bubble appearance)

Option D:  Sigmoid volvulus is the most common type of colonic volvulus and occurs when a portion of the intestine twists around its blood supply. It shows features like abdominal pain, constipation, vomiting, and a tyre-like feel of the abdomen. The plain radiograph shows the pathognomic omega sign and coffee bean sign.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with the findings below. He was born at 38 weeks of gestation to a mother who was retropositive. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
This child with oesophageal candidiasis and Kaposi's sarcoma as shown in the images respectively is most likely suffering from AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) clinical stage 4. The other feature seen in this stage is CMV (cytomegalovirus) retinitis. This is according to the WHO (World Health Organization) staging of AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection.

CMV retinitis is a common opportunistic ocular infection seen in patients who are retro-positive. Ocular symptoms of CMV infection include reduced vision, floaters, and anterior uveitis. In the later stages, the patient can develop cataracts. Retinitis usually starts in the periphery with flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages. The direct spread of the infection can lead to optic neuritis. It can result in visual loss if left untreated.

questions.text: The most common soft tissue sarcoma in the pediatric age group is______.
questions.solution:
Rhabdomyosarcoma, a tumor of striated skeletal muscle, is the most common pediatric soft tissue sarcoma.

The most common sites are- head and neck (25%) > genitourinary tract (24%) > extremities (19%) > orbit (9%).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivered a baby with the following anomaly. Further investigations revealed multiple anomalies like tracheoesophageal fistula, vertebral,  anal, cardiac, renal, and arterial defects. Which of the following drug taken by the mother is most likely to be responsible for the baby's condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a newborn with radial aplasia of the right arm. This feature, along with the given clinical presentation, describes VACTERL defects. This condition is associated with maternal intake of statins. 

VACTERL defects is an acronym for a group of congenital malformations which characteristically include:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular malformation
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia
  • Radial/Renal dysplasia
  • Limb anomalies

Genito-urinary anomalies (ambiguous genitalia, genitourinary fistula, cryptorchidism) and other system anomalies like facial asymmetry, external ear malformation, etc. can also be found in these patients.

VACTERL defects have been associated with maternal exposure to statins, doxorubicin, and lead. They are also associated with maternal diabetes.

Other options:

Option A: Penicillamine causes cutis laxa syndrome. Cutis laxa is a group of rare connective tissue disorders in which the skin becomes inelastic and hangs loosely in folds. Maternal exposure to penicillamine was found to be associated with cutis laxa in infants.

The image below shows cutis laxa:

 

Option B: Vitamin D causes supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Option C: Lithium causes Ebstein anomaly.

questions.text: An adolescent girl complains of dropping objects from her hands, these are precipitated during early morning hours and exams, and the frequency of such jerks increases whenever she is sleep-deprived. There is no history of loss of consciousness. One of her cousins has been diagnosed with epilepsy. What can be the most likely EEG finding in this case?

choices.text: 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep

questions.solution:
The diagnosis here is juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JME), which is characterized by isolated jerks, usually involving both arms; the jerks can be as subtle as finger twitches, but in this case, they manifest as dropping objects. 4-5 Hz epileptic spikes can be seen on the EEG in this condition.

Factors supporting the diagnosis:

  • The hallmark seizures in JME are myoclonic jerks, which are most frequent in the morning.
  • Consciousness is preserved.
  • The myoclonus in JME is epileptic, as opposed to physiologic or essential.
  • Patients may have reflex seizures triggered by various types of stimuli, such as writing, reading, praxis, or higher mental activities, and aggravated by sleep deprivation.

questions.text: A 14-month-old baby is being evaluated for cow's milk protein allergy. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Proctocolitis is a clinical manifestation of non-IgE mediated CMPA
Initial diagnosis is based on an elimination trial from the diet
It is the most common food protein allergy in children
This condition is dependent on quantity of milk given to the child

questions.solution:
Cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA) is an all or none phenomenon and does not depend on the quantity of milk administered to the child, unlike lactose intolerance which is dependent on quantity. This is one of the ways to differentiate between the two conditions.

CMPA:

  • It is the most common food protein allergy in children. 
  • It may be IgE-mediated, non-IgE-mediated or mixed (Food Protein Induced Enterocolitis Syndrome - FPIES).
  • Children may have respiratory, gastrointestinal, or cutaneous manifestations. 
  • Clinical features in IgE-mediated CMPA - Onset immediate to <1 hour. Immediate food hypersensitivity, perioral urticaria, erythema, angioedema, anaphylaxis, generalized rash, nausea, vomiting can be seen.
  • Clinical features in non-IgE-mediated CMPA - Onset >24 hrs, usually after 5-7 days.Can present with proctocolitis, enteropathy, enterocolitis, esophagitis, gastro-duodenitis, atopic dermatitis
  • The diagnosis is always clinical.
  • Diagnosis may be based on an elimination food trial for initial diagnosis followed by an oral food challenge. The duration of the elimination needed to observe clinical response varies from 3-5 days in IgE-mediated disease to a few weeks in others. 
  • Other methods for diagnosis include a scoring system for CMPA (CoMiSS - Cow Milk related symptom score), specific antibodies for diagnosis, skin prick tests and endoscopic evaluation. 
  • The safest strategy for management is avoidance of cow's milk from the diet for a defined period. Alternative substitutes may be considered. Unmodified mammalian milk should not be used in infants with proven CMPA. Appropriate options include hydrolyzed formula, soy formula above 6 months of age and amino acid formulas.
  • Most cases resolve by 4-5 years of age.

questions.text: A mother has brought her 6-month-old infant to a pediatrician for a regular checkup. She tells her baby's weight was approximately double the birth weight at 5 months of age. The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of:
questions.solution:
The baby's weight would be approximately triple the birth weight by the age of 1 year.  

Infant weight approximately doubles by the age of 5 months, triples by 1 year, and is 4 times by 2 years of age. Infants may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the 1st week of life as a result of excretion of excess extravascular fluid and limited nutritional intake. They regain their birth weight by their 2nd week and thereafter gain weight at specific rates at specific age groups.

The growth and development of a child between the age of 6-12 months can be classified as:

  • Physical Development:  By 12 months of age, birth weight has tripled, length has increased by 50%, and head circumference has increased by 10 cm. A mature pincer grasp occurs and tooth eruption has started to occur. Motor achievements correlate with increasing myelinization and cerebellar growth.
  • Cognitive Development: Object permanence appears by 9 months of age. The baby tries to search for a hidden object.
  • Emotional Development: Infants may cling or cry anxiously when a stranger approaches, demonstrating stranger anxiety. Separation anxiety can also seen.
  • Linguistic Development: Between 8 and 10 months of age, infants produce multisyllabic sounds (“ba-da-ma”) called canonical babbling. Babies can discriminate between languages.

Related Pearl: Weight and height changes in children

Term newborns may lose up to 10% of their birth weight in the first few days of life (due to extracellular fluid losses). Most healthy newborns typically regain their birth weight by 10 to 14 days. Thereafter, approximate daily weight gain is as follows :

questions.text: A 6-week-old female infant presented with the following appearance and a history of delayed passage of meconium and prolonged jaundice. There is no history of maternal drug intake during the intrauterine period. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Open posterior fontanel is an important indicator for this condition.
Jaundice occurs due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation.
Neurological and cognitive development are refractory to treatment.
TSH levels have a higher sensitivity for screening in this condition.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image (the hypotonic posture, macroglossia, coarse facial features, and umbilical hernia) are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism in the 6-week-old infant. Early diagnosis and treatment with thyroid hormone replacement prevent severe mental retardation and other neurologic complications. 

Screening for children for congenital hypothyroidism is very important; congenital hypothyroidism is known as the most common preventable cause of mental retardation. Children diagnosed beyond the neonatal period have a poor outcome. A dried blood sample is screened for TSH, usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally. 

Causes of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Goitrous (Palpable goiter):
    • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
    • Iodine deficiency
    • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Non-goitrous (No palpable goiter):
    • Thyroid dysgenesis
    • Thyroid receptor-blocking antibodies
    • Central hypothyroidism

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism become prominent with increasing age. 

  • Hoarse cry, facial puffiness, umbilical hernia, and unexplained hypothermia.
  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Open posterior fontanelle: Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with hematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

6 Ps:  Pot-bellied, Pale, Puffy-faced child with Protruding umbilicus, Protuberant tongue, and Poor brain development

Management: Thyroid replacement soon after the diagnosis. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is brought to the hospital by her concerned parents who observed some skin changes over her body. On examination, red and blue lacy, reticulated patterns can be observed on the trunk and limbs as seen below. The baby otherwise appears healthy and alert. This presentation is likely due to __________.

choices.text: Due to exposure to low environmental temperature
Due to arrested migration of melanocytes

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Cutis Marmorata. This usually is seen in an infant who is exposed to low environmental temperatures.

They appear as lacy, reticulated red or blue cutaneous vascular patterns over the body surface. It is caused by superficial small blood vessels in the skin dilating and contracting at the same time. It occurs as a result of an exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response. It is seen throughout infancy and in 50% of children. 

Rewarming restores the skin to normal. 

Note: Cutis Marmorata telangiectatic congenita is a distinct vascular developmental disorder and is easily distinguished as it is fixed (it does not disappear on rewarming), and it may be associated with a variety of other anomalies such as limb growth or renal anomalies.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

13. Physiological phimosis

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text:
You are an intern posted in a primary health center during the Community Medicine rotation. As a part of a health screening program, you are assigned the task of diagnosing and treating children with malnutrition in the community. A 2-year-old boy is brought to you for assessment. He is the son of a daily wage laborer and the youngest child among 5 siblings. He is stunted, with loose folds of skin and hollow cheeks but appears alert and eagerly takes the snack you offer him. Physical examination revealed the following:
  • Temperature: 96.5°F
  • Pulse Rate: 80/min
  • Blood Pressure: 90/60 mm Hg
  • Weight-for-height below −3 SD
  • Absence of facial and bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper-arm circumference is 11 cm

Which of the following is incorrect regarding his condition?

choices.text: The child is suffering from severe acute malnutrition.
The clinical scenario and findings are suggestive of marasmus.
The child should be provided with 175 kcal/kg body weight/day.
This child requires inpatient management in a facility.

questions.solution:
This child's presentation points towards the diagnosis of severe acute malnutrition or SAM (marasmus). This child can be treated under supervised home management as he has uncomplicated SAM, with a good appetite and absence of edema or any danger signs.

Clinical features of Marasmus

  • Head that appears large relative to the body, with staring eyes
  • Emaciated and weak appearance
  • Bradycardia, hypotension, and hypothermia
  • Thin, dry skin
  • Shrunken arms, thighs, and buttocks, with redundant skin folds caused by loss of subcutaneous fat
  • Thin, sparse hair that is easily plucked

Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in children of ages 6 to 59 months is defined by WHO as any of the following:

  • Weight-for-length (or height) below −3 SD of the WHO Child Growth Standards.
  • Presence of bipedal edema
  • Mid-upper arm circumference <11.5 cm

Assess for the following complications

  • Severe edema(+++), or
  • Low appetite (failed appetite test), or
  • Medical complications, or 
  • One or more danger sign as per IMNCI.

Presence of any one of these is characteristic of complicated SAM and requires inpatient management in a facility. Uncomplicated SAM can be managed under supervised home care.

Supervised Home Management of Uncomplicated SAM. Children with uncomplicated SAM can be managed at home provided:

• Family is counseled and fully engaged.
• Community health worker(s) and peer counselors are involved to support the family.
• Supply of adequate home food and ready to use therapeutic food (RUTF), if possible.
• Periodic monitoring for growth and medical condition can be ensured.

The child should be provided with 175 kcal/kg body weight/day.

 

 

The previous name protein-energy malnutrition is avoided, as it oversimplifies the complex multi-deficiency etiology.

Treatment:

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Phases: 

Initial stabilization phase :

(mnemonic: SHIELDED- Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia), Hypothermia, Infection, ELectrolyte imbalance, DEhydration, Deficiency of nutrients)

  • Focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions.
  • 2-7 days of inpatient treatment

Rehabilitation phase: 

  • Focuses on rebuilding wasted tissues
  • Takes several weeks

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (Blood glucose level<54 mg/dl): if symptomatic give 10% Dextrose IV 5ml/kg; Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (Formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care (“kangaroo technique”) or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14.
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
  • Start cautious feeding : Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 to provide 130 mL/kg/day,100 kcal/kg/day, and 1 to 1.5 g protein/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal edema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

A child with SAM may be considered to have completed treatment when:

  • There is no edema for at least 2 weeks +
  • Weight-for-height (or length) reaches -2 SD or higher or mid-upper-arm circumference is more than 12.5 cm

questions.text: A mother is advised that the baby should be allowed to empty one breast completely before switching over to the other for optimum growth. All the following are reasons for this, except ____.

choices.text: Foremilk is rich in  sugar and vitamins

questions.solution:
While breastfeeding, the mother should allow complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both fore-milk and hind-milk for optimum growth. Hind milk is rich in fats that provide more energy.

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

questions.text: Parents of a child with febrile seizures are concerned about its relapse, complications, and treatment. All of the following are true regarding the risks and management of this case, except:

choices.text: Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of a recurrent febrile seizure
Nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam, help to reduce the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures
Antiepileptic therapy can decrease the risk of future epilepsy
Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures

questions.solution:
All of the above statements are true, except for option C. Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.

Febrile seizures are seizures that:

  • Occur between the age of 6 months and 5 years
  • Occur at a temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher
  • Are not due to any CNS infection or any metabolic imbalance
  • Occur without a history of prior afebrile seizures
  • Occur with no post-ictal neurological deficit.

Antipyretics do not reduce the risk of recurrent febrile seizures.

Types of febrile seizures:

Simple febrile seizures Complex (atypical) febrile seizures
Occurs within 24 hours of the onset of fever Can occur at any time during a fever
Generalized seizures Focal seizures
Duration is <15 min Prolonged
No recurrence within 24 hrs of seizures Recurrent
Chances of going into epilepsy 1% Chances of going into epilepsy 6%

Investigations:

  • Lumbar puncture should be performed in the first episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months age (to exclude meningitis).
  • EEG and neuroimaging are advised for children with atypical febrile seizures.

Treatment:

Antipyretics and proper hydration. Midazolam or diazepam (rectal) can be used if seizures present.

Prophylaxis:

  • Intermittent prophylaxis: If the febrile seizures are 3 or more in 6 months, or 4 or more seizures in 1 year, oral clobazam (1mg/kg/day) for 3 days during the fever episode.
  • Continuous prophylaxis: If intermittent prophylaxis fails and in recurrent atypical febrile seizures, sodium valproate and phenobarbitone can be used.

Note:

  • Antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but do not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.
  • Intermittent oral nitrazepam, clobazam, and clonazepam have also been used. Such therapies help reduce, but do not eliminate, the risks of recurrence of febrile seizures.
  • Future epilepsy does not change with or without antiepileptic therapy.
  • Iron deficiency is associated with an increased risk of febrile seizures, and thus screening and treating it would be appropriate.

Risk Factors for Recurrence of Febrile Seizures:

Major:

  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hr
  • Fever 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F)

Minor:

  • Daycare
  • Male gender
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Lower serum sodium at time of presentation

questions.text: A neonate is brought with complaints of recurrent bilious vomiting for the past few hours. He was born at 37 weeks gestation and weighed 2.7 kg. The mother was diagnosed with polyhydramnios during pregnancy. His abdominal X-ray shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette and the radiograph showing the presence of a double bubble sign are strongly suggestive of duodenal atresia. 

Duodenal atresia occurs due to failure of recanalization of the duodenal lumen during the gestational period. 

It is associated with various conditions including prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and maternal polyhydramnios. It is also associated with malformations of the hepatobiliary system such as the annular pancreas and biliary atresia.

In most cases, this duodenal obstruction is seen distal to the ampulla of Vater. Hence, infants present with bilious vomiting and features of intestinal obstruction soon after birth. On examination, the upper abdomen is distended with a scaphoid lower abdomen. 

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. Other investigations include abdominal radiographs that show the double-bubble sign. If distal air is present, an upper GI contrast study should be done to exclude midgut volvulus, which is a surgical emergency.

Definitive management is by surgical bypass of the obstruction as a side-to-side or transverse to longitudinal (diamond-shaped) duodenoduodenostomy. 

Other options:

Option A: In congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis the abdominal radiograph will show a single enlarged gastric gas bubble. 

Option C: In jejunal atresia the abdominal radiograph will show a triple bubble sign.

Option D: In colonic atresia the abdominal radiograph will show multiple dilated bowel loops and differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presented with oliguria, hypertension, facial puffiness, and dark-colored urine as shown below for 3 days. The urine is positive for albumin. He had a history of throat infection 2 weeks back. On microscopic examination, enlarged, pale glomeruli and epithelial humps are seen. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: C3 level increases and ASO level increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level  increases
C3 level decreases and ASO level  decreases
C3 level  increases and  ASO level  decreases

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given in the question is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Decreased levels of C3 and elevated levels of ASO titers are seen in acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis. 

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis(PSGN) is characterized by the sudden onset of gross hematuria, edema, hypertension, and renal insufficiency. It usually occurs following a throat infection by nephritogenic strains of group A β-hemolytic streptococci. It can also occur after streptococcal skin infection or pyoderma.

The typical patient develops an acute nephritic syndrome following:
  • 1 to 2 weeks after an antecedent streptococcal pharyngitis or
  • 3 to 6 weeks after streptococcal pyoderma

The pathogenesis involves circulating antibodies elicited by streptococcal antigens reacting with normal glomerular antigens and complement activation by directly deposited streptococcal antigens causing the immunologic injury. In this immune complex-mediated APSGN, we see the following in most patients:

  • Decrease in the serum complement (C3) level (levels normalize in 6 to 8 weeks)
  • ASO titer is increased
Microscopic Findings in PSGN:
  • Light microscopy: Enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with diffuse mesangial and endothelial proliferation and leukocyte infiltration.
  • Immunofluorescence: Granular deposits of IgG and complement C3 along the glomerular basement membrane(GBM)and in the mesangium. 
  • Electron microscopy: Electron-dense deposits, or humps, are observed on the epithelial side of the GBM.

Match the following metabolic derangements with their most likely presentations -
  Metabolic derangement   Clinical presentation
A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency 1. Splenomegaly, avascular necrosis, and delayed puberty
B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency 2. Copious nasal discharge, corneal clouding, dysostosis multiplex
C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency 3. Hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, doll-like facies
D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase 4. Extreme irritability, developmental delay, optic atrophy
    5. Hepatomegaly, vomiting, cataracts, and sepsis
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-2, and D-5.

A. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency is seen in Von Gierke disease which is a glycogen storage disorder (Type Ia). Patients with GSD Type I present with a protruding abdomen due to hepatomegaly, doll-like facies, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, organomegaly, seizures, and pulmonary hypertension. It is an autosomal recessive disorder 

B. Beta-galactosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe's disease which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It is an autosomal recessive disorder that results from the deficiency of galactocerebrosidase. The classic manifestations that would suggest Krabbe's disease include irritability, seizures, and hypertonia.  Optic atrophy and developmental delay are other features.

C. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency is seen in Hurler syndrome,  a type of mucopolysaccharidosis type I.  Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex. Corneal clouding, short stature, and copious nasal discharge are other features.

D. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency is seen in classical galactosemia. Clinical features include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and sepsis. They also tend to develop cataracts.

questions.text: A term infant with a birth weight of 3.2 kg develops jaundice at day 2 of life. It first appeared on the sclera and progressed to the trunk with a total bilirubin of 11mg/dL by day 4. He was managed with the following procedure. Choose the incorrect option regarding this procedure.

choices.text: 460–490 nm wavelength of light is used in this procedure.
Loose stools and dehydration are common complications.
Bronze baby syndrome is a contraindication for this procedure.
Irreversible structural isomerization is the most important mechanism.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of neonatal jaundice and the procedure shown in the image is phototherapy. The incorrect option regarding the procedure is that bronze baby syndrome is a contraindication for this procedure. 

Bronze baby syndrome is a complication associated with phototherapy. It is a dark, grayish-brown skin discoloration seen in infants with direct hyperbilirubinemia undergoing phototherapy. Phototherapy can be continued in such cases if required. Porphyria is a contraindication for phototherapy.

Complications associated with phototherapy include: 

  • Loose stools
  • Erythematous macular rash
  • Purpuric rash associated with transient porphyrinemia
  • Overheating
  • Dehydration (increased insensible water loss, diarrhea)
  • Hypothermia from exposure

The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonatal indirect hyperbilirubinemia ranges from 460–490 nm (blue-green light). It is more effective than blue light (430 to 470 nm) due to the following reasons:

  • It converts bilirubin to harmless forms.
  • Its longer wavelength (460 to 490 nm) enhances skin penetration
  • Pure blue light can mask cyanosis in an infant

Clinical jaundice and indirect hyperbilirubinemia are reduced by exposure to the high intensity of light in the visible spectrum by 3 mechanisms:

  • Irreversible structural isomerization: Most important mechanism; acts by forming lumirubin from native bilirubin. It is then excreted by the kidneys in the unconjugated state
  • Reversible photo-isomerization: Converts toxic unconjugated bilirubin into an unconjugated configurational isomer. It is then excreted in bile without conjugation
  • Photo-oxidation: minor method

Phototherapy can be discontinued once two TSB (total serum bilirubin) values 12 hours apart fall below current age-specific cut-offs.

Sn-mesoporphyrin (SnMP), a synthetic metalloporphyrin is a potential alternative medical therapy for neonatal jaundice. It acts by competitive inhibition of the conversion of heme protein to biliverdin by heme oxygenase. A single intramuscular dose on the 1st day of life reduces the need for subsequent phototherapy. Complication from metalloporphyrins includes transient erythema if the infant is receiving phototherapy

Assessing the level of jaundice: 

Kramer described dermal staining of bilirubin. It is used as a clinical guide in assessing the level of jaundice.

questions.text: An 11-month-old child is brought to the emergency room with a history of 12-14 episodes of loose, watery stools which is not blood-stained for the last two days. On examination, the temperature is 98.8 deg F, pulse rate is 130/min, and respiratory rate is 45/min. The child appears lethargic with sunken eyes and skin turgor is reduced with recoil in 3 secs. Which of the following is incorrect about the management protocol in this patient as per the WHO IMNCI plans?

choices.text: The fluid replacement should be done over 6 hours
Both Ringer's lactate and normal saline can be used for resuscitation
The total fluid requirement in this patient is 75ml/kg
ORS can be given as a bridge to definitive management

questions.solution:
The child presenting with watery diarrhea, lethargy, sunken eyes, and skin pinch going back very slowly(longer than 2 seconds) is classified as severe dehydration. 100 ml/kg of ringer’s lactate solution or if not available, normal saline is given over 6 hours.

According to the IMNCI classification, the child should be treated according to plan C. The child is transferred urgently to the hospital and the mother is advised to give frequent sips of ORS along the way.

This child should be started on IV fluids immediately. 100 ml/kg of ringer’s lactate solution or if not available, normal saline can be given over 6 hours as the child is less than 12 months of age. If the child can drink ORS(Oral rehydration solution) should be given by mouth while the drip is set up. 

As soon as the child can drink, ORS is given at about 5 ml/kg/hour, which is usually after 3-4 hours (infants) or 1-2 hours (children).

choices.text: Increase in FEV1> 12% after salbutamol inhalation

questions.solution:
Day-night variation of FEV1 > 15% is not suggestive of asthma, variation ≥20% is suggestive of asthma.

Lung Function Abnormalities in Childhood Asthma

  • Spirometry showing airflow limitation: Low FEV1 (relative to the percentage of predicted norms) and FEV1:FVC ratio <0.80 (option B)
  • Bronchodilator response (to inhaled β-agonist): Improvement in FEV1 ≥12% and ≥200 mL after inhalation of a short-acting beta agonist (option A).
  • Exercise challenge: Worsening in FEV1 ≥15% (option D)
  • Daily peak expiratory flow (PEF) or FEV1 monitoring: day to day and/or A.M.-to-P.M. variation ≥20%

FEV1: Forced expiratory volume in 1 sec; FVC: Forced vital capacity. 

Childhood asthma can be classified into two types: recurrent wheezing in early childhood, often triggered by respiratory viral infections and resolves during preschool/lower school years, and chronic asthma associated with allergies that persist into later childhood and adulthood.

questions.text: An exclusively breastfed neonate in his 4th week of life was found to have jaundice. His stools are yellow and his urine is pale straw yellow-colored. He is otherwise well. Blood tests show unconjugated bilirubinemia. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given child is exclusively breastfed, whose stools and urine appear normal, along with unconjugated bilirubinemia suggests breast milk jaundice.

Breast milk jaundice is uncommon and is seen in exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 3-4 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain pregnanediol and β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption. Breastfeeding is not contraindicated in breast milk jaundice. Mothers are advised to continue breastfeeding at frequent intervals.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has had a fever for the past 5 days. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy of the right side, congested pharynx, and dry cracked lips. A throat swab is done and the rapid strep test is negative. The child has a maculopapular rash, and changes in the tongue and hands as shown in the image. Considering the most likely diagnosis, what would be the treatment protocol for this patient?

choices.text: Treated with prednisolone (2 mg/kg) and low-dose aspirin
Treated with prednisolone (2 mg/kg) and high-dose aspirin
Treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and low-dose aspirin
Treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease. Children with acute Kawasaki disease should be treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day) as soon as possible after the diagnosis.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness in childhood seen worldwide. It is a vasculitis with a predilection for the coronary arteries. About 20-25% of untreated children develop coronary artery abnormalities including aneurysms. Therefore, Echocardiography should be performed at diagnosis and after 2-3 weeks of illness.

Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease:

  • Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 years
  • Male sex
  • Fever ≥14 days
  • Hematocrit <35 percent 
  • Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L
  • White blood cell count >12,000/mm3

questions.text: A term baby is noted to have a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth. He was delivered by normal vaginal delivery with vertex presentation. The most likely site of the swelling noted in this baby would be:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the baby has developed a diffuse edematous swelling on the scalp immediately after birth suggestive of caput succedaneum. The most likely site of this swelling is represented by the structure marked as 1 in the image.

1- Caput succedaneum is a diffuse edematous collection in the soft tissues of the scalp with vertex presentation. It can extend across skull sutures and disappears within the first week of life.

2- Cephalohematoma is a subperiosteal hemorrhage. It occurs following instrumental delivery which results in rupture of emissary veins of the skull. It does not cross suture lines. The swelling appears only several hours after birth. They are resorbed within two weeks to 3 months, depending on their size.

3- Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood under the aponeurosis of the scalp. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. It can occur in hereditary coagulopathies and is associated with skull fractures.

4- Epidural hemorrhage is usually traumatic in origin. These are associated with cephalo-pelvic disproportion, prolonged labor, breech, precipitous labors, or as a result of mechanical assistance in labor. Majority resolve with no intervention.

questions.text: During the examination of a 2-month-old infant, you have observed that the umbilical cord is still firmly attached, and there is infection of cord stump. Which of the following would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Delayed separation of umbilical cord, after 1 month is associated with leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes.

The umbilical cord usually separates by 10-14 days after birth, although in about 10% of healthy infants, it may separate at the age of 3 weeks or later.

An intact cord after 1 month of birth is called delayed separation.

Leukocyte adhesion deficiency (LAD) syndromes:

  • LADs are autosomal recessive disorders characterized by defects in the function of neutrophils that include adhesion, motility, and ability to phagocytose bacteria.
  • As a result, the children may have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to reduced immune response, despite increased neutrophil count.
  • There is delayed separation of the cord, which is usually associated with infection of the cord stump.

There are three types of LAD:

  • LAD 1- Defective beta 2 integrin (CD18), leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and defective tight adhesion. 
  • LAD 2- Reduced phagocyte surface expression of sialyl-Lewis X, leading to abnormal neutrophil rolling.
  • LAD 3- Defective signaling for integrin activation, leading to abnormal neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion. (milder than type 1)

questions.text:
Which among the following disorders does not follow the classic mendelian inheritance?
  1. Angelman syndrome
  2. Marfan syndrome
  3. Kearns-Sayre syndrome
  4. Prader -Willi syndrome
  5. Duchenne muscular dystrophy
questions.solution:
Out of the given options, Angelman syndrome (1), Kearns-Sayre syndrome (3), and Prader-Willi syndrome (4) do not follow a classic Mendelian inheritance pattern.

The classic forms of genetic inheritances such as autosomal dominant, autosomal recessive, and X-linked inheritance are referred to as Mendelian inheritance forms.

Autosomal dominant inheritance is marked by the presence of one abnormal gene on one of the autosomes/ chromosomes 1-22. Autosomal recessive inheritance requires both copies of the same to be abnormal. If genes located on the X chromosome are affected, an X-linked pattern of inheritance with males being affected more commonly is seen. 

The non-mendelian inheritance pattern is used to describe mitochondrial inheritance, trinucleotide repeat disorders, and genetic imprinting.

Angelman syndrome and Prader-Willi syndrome arise due to genetic imprinting. Here, the gene expression depends on the parental origin of the chromosome. It results due to an imbalance in the active copies of a specific gene. In Angelman syndrome, the maternal copy is affected while the paternal one is affected in Prader-Willi syndrome. Both the syndromes present with developmental delays and mental retardation. 

Marfan's syndrome follows an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance. Features include tall stature, arachnodactyly, lens subluxation, and aortic root dilatation. 

Kearns-Sayre syndrome is a mitochondrial disorder that results in lactic acidosis, pigmentary retinitis, and progressive external ophthalmoplegia. 

Duchenne muscular dystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder that is characterized by the involvement of the proximal muscles of the lower limbs. Calf hypertrophy is a characteristic feature.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presented with dark-colored urine. His father suffered from a similar condition and has grade 5 chronic kidney disease and is undergoing dialysis. Although a light-microscopy was normal, electron microscopy reveals the findings attached in the image given below. Which of the following clinical features /findings are expected in this patient?
  1. Macular flecks
  2. Posterior lenticonus
  3. Conductive hearing loss
  4. Hematuria
  5. Proteinuria
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the basket-weave appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy are highly suggestive of Alport syndrome. The clinical features expected in this patient are macular flecks, hematuria, and proteinuria. The correct options are 1, 4, and 5.

Alport syndrome or hereditary nephritis is due to mutations in the genes coding for type IV collagen. The majority have X-linked inheritance.

Patients present with asymptomatic microscopic or gross hematuria, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities like anterior lenticonus, macular flecks, and corneal erosions. Proteinuria exceeding 1 gram per day is seen by the 2nd decade of life.

Light microscopy of the glomerulus appears normal during the early stages. As the disease progress, mesangial proliferation and capillary wall thickening may be seen, leading to glomerular sclerosis. Foam cells which are lipid-containing tubular or interstitial cells develop during the later stages.

Electron microscopic features include irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and splitting, giving a basket-weave appearance.

questions.text: A young boy is brought to the clinician by his parents with complaints of impulsive behavior and decreased levels of attention at school and everyday activities. The clinician is suspecting a case of ADHD. Which of the following is not included in the criteria for diagnosis of ADHD?

choices.text: Symptoms begin before 7 years of age
Symptoms should be present for at least 6 months
Should be reported by independent observers
Behaviour must be developmentally inappropriate  in two or more settings

questions.solution:
Attention-deficit hyperactive disorder (ADHD) must begin before 12 years of age, according to DSM-5 criteria. It was 7 years as per the previous DSM-4 criteria.

DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for attention-deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)-
1. A persistent pattern of inattention and/or hyperactivity/impulsivity present for at least 6 months, that interferes with functioning or development.
2. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms were present before 12 years of age.
3. Several inattentive or hyperactive/impulsive symptoms are present in 2 or more settings (e.g., at school [or work] or at home) and is documented independently.
4. There is clear evidence of clinically significant impairment in social, academic, or occupational functioning.
 5. Symptoms do not occur exclusively during the course of schizophrenia, or another psychotic disorder, and are not better accounted for by another mental disorder (e.g., mood disorder, anxiety disorder, dissociative disorder, personality disorder, substance intoxication or withdrawal).

 

Treatment: Presynaptic dopaminergic agonists, commonly called psychostimulant medications, including methylphenidate, dexmethylphenidate, amphetamine, and various amphetamine and dextroamphetamine preparations are used.

A recent trial shows that Omega-3 fish oil supplements can improve attention in children with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD)  as much as drug treatments, but only in those whose blood levels of omega-3 are low.

questions.text: A neonate is brought to the pediatrician with complaints of bilious vomiting. An abdominal radiograph shows the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows the presence of a double bubble sign which is a feature of the duodenal atresia.

Duodenal atresia is the blockade of the duodenum caused due to the failure of the vacuolization of the solid duodenum. It is associated with prematurity, Down’s syndrome, and polyhydramnios.

It is usually identified during the prenatal ultrasound, where it shows the presence of a double bubble sign. If the atresia goes unnoticed during the prenatal period, the babies usually present with bilious vomiting soon after birth. This is because the obstruction is distal to the ampulla of Vater in most cases. Abdominal radiographs also show the double-bubble sign if done before orogastric tube decompression. It is treated by duodenoduodenostomy.

Other options:

Option A: Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis will show the presence of an enlarged gastric gas bubble /single bubble. It is seen at 2-8 weeks of life, more commonly in boys. It presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting which can lead to hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Visible gastric peristalsis can also be observed.

Option B: Jejunal atresia on an abdominal radiograph shows the triple bubble sign. It is the most common type of gastrointestinal atresia. Presenting features include bilious vomiting, abdominal distention, and failure to pass meconium.

Option D:  Colonic atresia is the least common type of intestinal atresia. A plain radiograph shows multiple dilated bowel loops, but differentiation between small and large bowel is not possible in neonates. A contrast enema study can confirm the diagnosis. The contrast does not pass proximally to the sigmoid colon as seen in the image.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text:
Match the given X-rays with their most likely clinical presentation.

 1. A 3-year-old with a history of cyanosis, effort intolerance, fatigue, and paroxysmal attacks of tachycardia.

 2. A 10-week-old neonate with irritability, failure to thrive, cardiomegaly with the onset of congestive cardiac failure at 8 weeks of life.

 3. A 12-year-old boy with h/o cyanotic spells, exercise intolerance, and dyspnea on exertion relieved by squatting.

 4. A week-old neonate with rapid breathing, severe cyanosis, and congestive cardiac failure.
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2.

A - 3: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)-  A 12-year-old boy with h/o cyanotic spells, exercise intolerance, and dyspnea on exertion relieved by squatting.

 Chest X-ray describes "Coeur en sabot" or boot-shaped heart, which is seen in the tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).

  • "Coeur en sabot" is due to cardiac apex elevation as a result of right ventricular hypertrophy. The cardiac silhouette has been likened to that of a boot.
  • The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively clear because of diminished pulmonary blood flow or the small size of the pulmonary arteries.
  • The aorta is usually large.
  • A characteristic fashion in which older children with tetralogy of Fallot increase pulmonary blood flow is to squat. Squatting is a compensatory mechanism, it increases peripheral vascular resistance (PVR) and thus decreases the magnitude of the right-to-left shunt across the ventricular septal defect (VSD).

B - 4: Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)- A week-old neonate with rapid breathing, severe cyanosis, and congestive cardiac failure.

 In transposition of great arteries, the heart appears globular (like an egg) due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement. The superior mediastinum appears narrow which gives the appearance of an egg-on-a-string. 

Infants with transposition of the great arteries (TGA) are usually born at term, with cyanosis apparent within hours of birth.

C - 1: Ebstein's Anamoly - A 3-year-old with a history of cyanosis, effort intolerance, fatigue, and paroxysmal attacks of tachycardia.

In Ebstein’s anomaly, the radiological sign seen is a box-shaped heart. Cyanosis is fairly common and frequently due to right-to-left shunt at the atrial level and/or severe heart failure. Fatigue and dyspnea are due to poor cardiac output secondary to right ventricular failure and decreased left ventricular ejection fraction. Palpitations and sudden cardiac death may occur due to paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) 

 

D - 2: Total Anomalous Pulmonary venous connection (TAPVC) - A 10-week-old neonate with irritability, failure to thrive, minimal cyanosis, cardiomegaly with the onset of congestive cardiac failure at 8 weeks of life.

 In Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection, the radiograph shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. 

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into the left atrium drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly.

 The following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infra-cardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into the hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient presents with delayed puberty. Investigations reveal increased levels of gonadotropins. Which among the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient has increased levels of gonadotropins pointing towards Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and Klinefelter's syndrome is the only condition in the given choices causing hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

Klinefelter's syndrome is the most common sex chromosomal aneuploidy in males. Most of them have 47 XXY chromosomes. The diagnosis is rarely made before puberty, behavioral or psychiatric disorders may be apparent long before the defects in sexual development.

Causes of delayed puberty:

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (Secondary/central):

Hypogonadism due to the impaired secretion of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) by the pituitary gland and the resultant lack of sex steroid production

  • Malnutrition, systemic diseases
  • Kallmann (anosmia), Prader–Willi syndrome (mental retardation, obesity, low intelligence)

Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism (Primary gonadal failure):

Hypogonadism due to an impaired response of the gonads to the gonadotropins (FSH and LH), which in turn leads to a lack of sex steroid production and elevated gonadotropin levels (as an attempt of compensation by the body)

  • Sex chromosome anomalies (Turner's, Klinefelter's syndrome)
  • Androgen insensitivity syndrome
  • Ovotesticular dysgenesis

questions.text: A 4-year-old fully immunized boy was brought to the emergency department with complaints of dysphagia, fever, and drooling. On a lateral x-ray of the neck, a characteristic thumb sign was seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of a toxic-looking child with an x-ray of the neck showing thumb sign are suggestive of acute epiglottitis. 

Acute epiglottitis is an acute rapidly progressive inflammation of the epiglottis causing obstructive laryngitis. It is caused chiefly by Haemophilus influenzae type b.

Patients present with high fever, sore throat, dysphagia, tachycardia, systemic toxicity, and drooling as patients are unable to swallow. The patient characteristically assumes a tripod position, sitting upright and leaning forward with the chin up and mouth open.

The diagnosis often is made on clinical grounds. On direct fiberoptic laryngoscopy, the typical edematous cherry-red epiglottis is visualized. Neck radiographs reveal an enlarged edematous epiglottis (thumb sign).

The image given below shows the thumb sign seen in epiglottitis.

Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency due to sudden and unpredictable airway obstruction. The treatment includes the following:

  • Admission to the intensive care unit
  • Airway management - endotracheal or nasotracheal intubation or, less often, by tracheostomy, regardless of the degree of apparent respiratory distress
  • Antibiotics - Parenteral ampicillin or third-generation cephalosporins
  • Dexamethasone may be given to reduce pharyngeal edema
  • Adequate hydration and humidified oxygen

Other options:

Option A: Croup or acute laryngotracheobronchitis is gradual in onset and is usually preceded by prodromal symptoms. Also, fever is usually absent in such patients. X-ray of the chest shows typically a steeple sign due to narrowing of subglottic space.

The image given below shows the steeple sign seen in croup.

Option C: It is unlikely to be laryngeal diphtheria as it is mentioned that the child is fully immunized, and diphtheria is typically associated with membrane formation. 

The image given below shows membrane formation seen in diphtheria.

Option D: Retropharyngeal abscess is seen secondary to infections and usually does not present with fever. Children usually present with a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, lateral to the midline. It is confirmed by a lateral X-ray of the neck which shows a widening of the prevertebral shadow.

The image given below shows x-ray findings seen in a retropharyngeal abscess.

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents with coarse facial features and enlarging hands and feet. His height is above 2 standard deviations for his age. He also complains of headaches and visual problems. The parents complain about behavioural problems. There is an elevated level IGF-1 level for age and no suppression of GH  in a glucose tolerance test. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette suggests the cause to be pituitary gigantism. It is caused by the overproduction of growth hormone.  It is seen in younger age groups before the closure of epiphysis.

It is a rare condition, caused mostly by pituitary adenoma

Clinical features include-

  • Longitudinal growth acceleration secondary to GH excess.
  • Coarse facial features
  • Enlarging hands and feet
  • Rapid growth of the head can precede linear growth
  • Behavioral problems
  • Visual problems.
  • Delayed puberty.
  • Local effects- headache, visual field defects, and other hormone deficiencies.
  • Some cases also show acromegalic features.

GH levels are elevated. There is no normal suppression of GH levels induced by a glucose tolerance test. There are elevated levels of IGF-1 and IGFBP-3. MRI and CT imaging will show a pituitary adenoma.

The treatment options are surgical removal of well-circumscribed masses trans-sphenoidally or trans-cranially. Radiation and medical therapy may be required in some cases.

Medical Therapy-

  • Somatostatin analogues like octreotide and lanreotide suppress GH levels.
  • Bromocriptine and cabergoline can be when there is concomitant prolactin oversecretion. 
  • Pegvisomant is a GH receptor antagonist that causes effective suppression of IGF and GH levels.

Other options:

Option A: Overproduction of GH results in acromegaly which is seen in young adults after the closure of epiphyses. 

Option B: McCune–Albright syndrome is a classical cause of peripheral precocious puberty caused by a mutation of the GNAS1 gene. It affects the bones, skin, and several endocrine tissues.

Cardinal features:

  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Cafe au lait macules
  • Endocrine abnormalities: hyperthyroidism, acromegaly, adrenal adenomas, and autonomous ovarian hyperfunction, leading to precocious puberty
  • Predominantly affects girls

Note: Precocious puberty in boys is the onset of secondary sexual characteristics before the age of nine years. 

Option C: Cushing syndrome results from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It presents with weight gain, central obesity, hypertension, and hypokalemia. Other clinical features include thin, brittle skin with easy bruisability, purple stretch marks, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and osteopenia.

questions.text: A male baby was born by a cesarean section for obstructed labor. On examination of the baby, the anterior and posterior fontanels were wide open, the sutures were widely separated and the occiput was very prominent. MRI imaging showed the following finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows the dilation of the fourth ventricle with hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis. The diagnosis is likely to be Dandy-Walker syndrome. It is a congenital malformation that involves cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, hydrocephalus, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. It is associated with the atresia of the foramen of Magendie.

Other options

Option A- Mega cisterna magna can also cause hydrocephalus. It is characterized by an enlarged CSF space inferior and dorsal to the cerebellar vermis.

Option B- Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, ataxia, breathing abnormalities including episodic apnea and hyperpnea. Imaging will show the presence of cerebellar vermis hypoplasia and molar tooth sign (a deepening of the interpeduncular fossa with thick and straight superior cerebellar peduncles)

Option C- Chiari malformation is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain. It consists of the herniation of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum. Often, there is also an associated developmental abnormality of the bones of the skull base leading to a small posterior fossa.

questions.text: A child is brought with fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation. CSF examination shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes with the predominance of neutrophils. How long should a child be isolated in this case to prevent further transmission?
questions.solution:
Isolation is recommended until 24 hrs after the initiation of effective therapy in bacterial meningitis. Fever, convulsions, and signs of meningeal irritation (nuchal rigidity, Kernig's sign, Brudzinski's signs) in a child, with CSF showing reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes levels is a typical presentation of bacterial meningitis.

Guidelines for prophylaxis:

  • All patients admitted to the hospital with meningitis should be placed on standard precautions.
  • Droplet precautions are recommended for patients with Neisseria meningitidis and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) meningitis until they have received 24 hours of effective therapy.
  • Patients should be in private rooms, and hospital personnel should wear a face mask when they are within 3 feet (1 meter) of the patient.
