questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl child is brought to the clinic by her father with a history of abdominal pain and diarrhea. Examination reveals an irritable child with darkening around both eyes and rapid jerky eye movements. There is a palpable abdominal mass with abdominal distention. Laboratory examination shows hypokalemia. Imaging shows an abdominal mass that is resected. Histopathological examination shows a small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. Diagnosis of a childhood tumor is established. Which of the following statements are true regarding this tumor?
  1. C-MYC is the oncogene affected in this patient
  2. Diarrhea and hypokalemia in the patient is a paraneoplastic syndrome associated with this tumor
  3. Most cases arise from the kidney
  4. Most cases arise from the adrenal glands
  5. Urinary catecholamines may be used for both diagnosis and monitoring of this tumor
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of neuroblastoma. The child presents with abdominal pain and a mass. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic Homer-Wright pseudorosettes which point towards the diagnosis. The diarrhea, hypokalemia and ocular features in this patient are a result of the paraneoplastic syndromes associated with this condition. This tumor arises from the adrenal glands and urinary catecholamines may be used to diagnose and monitor this tumor.

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumors in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. There has been an association established with fetal alcohol syndrome, neurofibromatosis, fetal hydantoin syndrome and Hirschsprung's disease.

Genetics - Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The N-MYC gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favorable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Clinical features:

Approximately two-thirds of the cases arise in the abdomen and most of these cases arise from the adrenal glands. Other sites include the organs of ZuckerKandl, posterior mediastinum, pelvis, head, and neck. 

The symptoms associated with this condition are -

  • abdominal mass (retroperitoneal or hepatic)
  • Pain - abdominal pain or localized back pain or bone pain
  • constipation
  • proptosis
  • periorbital ecchymoses ("raccoon eyes," from periorbital ecchymosis caused by orbital metastases)
  • Horner syndrome (miosis, ptosis, anhidrosis)
  • weakness (from spinal cord compression)
  • scoliosis
  • bladder dysfunction
  • palpable non-tender subcutaneous nodules
  • opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • secretory diarrhea (from paraneoplastic production of vasoactive intestinal polypeptide [VIP])
  • systemic symptoms (fever, weight loss)
  • anemia
  • heterochromia iridis (different colors of the iris or portions of the iris)
  • hypertension - due to secretion of catecholamines
  • unilateral nasal obstruction

Paraneoplastic syndrome:

  • Opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome - It occurs in about 1-3% of patients with neuroblastoma. The characteristics symptoms are rapid, dancing eye movements, rhythmic jerking (myoclonus) involving limbs or trunk, and/or ataxia.
  • Secretion of VIP - It causes abdominal distention and intractable secretory diarrhea with hypokalemia. Serum VIP levels will be >75 pg/ml

Diagnosis:

  • Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. A biopsy will show the presence of small round blue cell tumor with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes.
  • Other investigations that would aid in the diagnosis include CBC, urinary catecholamine excretion, bone marrow aspiration and biopsy, nuclear imaging with an I-131 MIBG scan, and CT to detect metastasis.

The mainstay of treatment is resection of the tumor, chemotherapy, and radiation. The tumors which have spread to other places will require surgery, chemotherapy, and radiotherapy. Important chemotherapeutic agents used are vincristine, cyclophosphamide, topotecan, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and etoposide.
